Heterogeneous hydrogenation with supported metal catalyst is one of the efficient methods for producing fine chemicals. Hydrogenation reactions for fine chemical production often use reactants with more than one unsaturated bond or involve cascade multiple-step reactions, facing the dilemma of activity and selectivity. The dual-site or multi-site catalysts have been employed to solve this dilemma, but the entanglement at different sites generally cannot improve selectivity without reducing activity. In this review, we will introduce recent progresses in the construction of dual-site supported metal catalysts with division of active site, which may break the tradeoff between activity and selectivity in selective hydrogenation considering that each active sites can be modulated separately without causing the property variation of other sites. In addition, such catalysts contribute to the basic understanding of their structure-activity relationship and provide a theoretical basis for the development of efficient hydrogenation catalysts for fine chemical production. Graphical Abstract This review mainly summarizes the recent progress in the preparation of SMCs with site division and their application in selective hydrogenations with focusing on enhancing both the activity and selectivity of SMCs by isolated active site in hydrogenation reactions. Keywords Selective hydrogenation Synergistic catalysis Isolated site Multi-site division Structure-activity relationship 1 Introduction Catalytic science and technology play a pivotal role in propelling the evolution of the modern chemical industry. Across diverse applications, from ammonia synthesis and petroleum refining to polymer and fine chemical production, the use of new catalysts continues to drive significant advancements in chemical processes [ 1–4 ]. Heterogeneous hydrogenation plays a crucial role in modern chemical industry and it is estimated that over 70%–80% of fine chemical production involves hydrogenation process [ 5–7 ]. The contemporary challenges posed by energy constraints, environmental issues and the imperative for sustainability requires the adoption of green production routes [ 8–10 ]. Consequently, there is an urgent need for a catalyst that can precisely transfer target specific chemical bonds with not only high activity but also 100% selectivity. In navigating these challenges, catalysis emerges as a key player in steering the chemical industry toward a more sustainable and efficient future. The supported metal catalysts (SMCs) are the most often used catalysts for heterogeneous hydrogenation [ 11–14 ]. Despite decades development of SMCs, achieving simultaneous improvements in both activity and selectivity still remains a formidable challenge. This challenge arises from the involvement of at least two different molecules, H2 and the reactant, both of which typically need to be adsorbed and activated on the active sites [ 15–20 ]. When H2 and the reactant share the same active sites, optimizing the adsorption strength towards H2, reactants, and products, as well as the adsorption configuration of reactants, becomes a complex task [ 21 ]. Consequently, enhancing both activity and selectivity under these conditions is difficult. In response to this challenge, the exploration of bi- or multi-site SMCs emerges as a promising strategy. These catalysts can utilize different types of active sites for the adsorption/activation of H2 and reactants, respectively, which opens new possibilities for advancing the efficiency of SMCs in heterogeneous hydrogenation. Dual/multi-site metal catalysts utilized in heterogeneous hydrogenation are primarily categorized into two types: collaborated metal and support dual-site and bimetallic dual-site. It is gradually recognized that the supports play an important role rather than remaining bystanders during the hydrogenation process beyond their conventional roles in dispersing and stabilizing metal nanoparticles [ 22 ]. For example, the oxygen vacancies (Ov) of metal oxides and metal cation (e.g., TiO2, CeO2, Nb2O5, MoO3) which could be modulated by strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) can serve as activation sites for reactants [ 23–25 ]. A noteworthy advantage lies in the selective adsorption of polar groups relative to non-polar groups on the Ov and metal cations, which significantly promotes the selectivity towards the hydrogenation of polar functional groups [ 24,26 ]. The acidic support such as zeolites and Nb2O5 could also cooperate with metal NPs [ 26,27 ] in isomerization [ 28,29 ], hydrodeoxygenation [ 30,31 ] and so on. Incorporating a second metal to form bimetallic synergistic sites is an effective strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance of monometallic catalysts. The combination of two metals can take various forms, including bimetallic alloys, amorphous bimetallic nanoparticles, single-atom alloys, or bimetallic nanoparticles with core-shell structures. The synergistic effect observed in bimetallic systems often not only arises from the modification of the geometric and electronic structure of the primary metal by the second metal, but also the participation of the second metal in the reaction [ 32 ]. As for most reported dual/multi-site SMCs, different active sites are entangled and it is hard to change the property of only one site without disturbing the other. Therefore, the increase in selectivity is often accompanied by the decrease in activity. For example, the SMSI can generate extra active sites on the support (e.g. Ov), but the electron and mass transfer from support to metal nanoparticles will change their surface structure and result in the active site capping. Therefore, the formation of SMSI can improve the selectivity, but deteriorate the activity of SMCs in selective hydrogenation [ 33,34 ]. The similar tendency was also observed for the bimetallic SMCs. Recently, the dual-site SMCs with the division of two active sites have been reported, and the tradeoff between activity and selectivity was broken off over these catalysts in selective hydrogenation. No direct contact between the two active sites allows their disentanglement, which makes it possible to regulate each active site independently. In addition, the dual-site SMCs facilitate in-depth understanding the function of each active site to elucidate the synergistic mechanisms of these sites in the reaction. The successful application of dual/multi-site SMCs in hydrogenation should be attributed to H2 spillover, which allows the hydrogenation of reactants and the dissociation of H2 to occur on distinct active sites, either in close proximity or physically separated [ 35–37 ]. It has been shown that the support significantly influences the efficiency and distance of hydrogen spillover. The hydrogen spillover capacity of reducible metal oxides and non-reducible metal oxides has been investigated [ 38–46 ]. A. van Bokhoven et al. [ 39 ] utilized single-particle x-ray in-situ absorption spectroscopy to investigate the hydrogen spillover distance and efficiency of TiO2 and Al2O3. The results indicate that the distance of hydrogen spillover can reach at least 45 nm on TiO2. Moreover, the hydrogen flux and the reducibility of spilled hydrogen were irrespective of distance. In contrast, the hydrogen spillover is much slower and confined to short distances (< 15 nm) on Al2O3. Additionally, the hydrogen flux decreases with distance, leading to the creation of a concentration gradient. Therefore, when dual isolated active sites are loaded on non-reducible supports, it is essential to consider the effect of hydrogen spillover distance on the synergistic effect. Consequently, it becomes feasible to independently modulate the properties of each site without mutual interference. This presents a significant opportunity to overcome the traditional trade-off between the activity and selectivity of SMCs. The synergy of the two/multi separated active sites resembles the biocatalysis, where different enzymes are spatially segregated into different compartments to prevent interference between enzymatic reactions, allowing cascade reactions with high activity and specificity. The SMCs with site division are also desirable model catalysts for resolving the complex and challenging task of identifying the reaction mechanism and the functions of active sites. In this critical review, we briefly summarize the recent progress in the preparation of SMCs with site division and their application in selective hydrogenations with focus on enhancing both the activity and selectivity of SMCs by isolated active sites in hydrogenation reactions, including the combination of two different metal NPs, metal NPs with single atom, metal NPs with porous materials, and metal NPs with metal complex. We hope that this critical review will serve as a source of inspiration for further elevating the catalytic performance of SMCs. 2 Combination of two spatially separated metal NPs The development of efficient catalysts relies on the profound understanding of reaction mechanism and structure-activity relationship. In most SMCs, the active sites for hydrogen activation and substrate hydrogenation are either the same or located so closely that investigating these processes separately becomes extremely challenging. Therefore, the use of multi-site catalysts with spatially separated active sites is essential to uncover the fundamental interactions between different active sites and their effects on catalytic behavior. The atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique plays a pivotal role in this pursuit by providing precise control for the preparation of catalysts at the atomic scale [ 47–52 ]. This innovative approach allows researchers to explore and manipulate catalytic processes at a level of detail previously unattainable, opening new avenues for advancing catalysis science and technology. Li et al. [ 53 ] fabricated exquisite Au/TiO2/Pt with sandwich nanostructure by ALD technology which achieves the spatial isolation of the active sites to investigate the task of different active sites separately in the hydrogenation of para-nitrothiophenol (pNTP) as shown in Figs. 1(a)–(c) . The TiO2 layer is positioned between the Pt film and the monolayer of Au nanoparticles. The substrate molecule para-nitrothiophenol (pNTP) selectively adsorbs on the surface of Au. In the hydrogenation of pNTP, no reaction occurs on Au/TiO2, indicating that the very large Au nanoparticles are incapable of activating hydrogen. However, the efficient hydrogenation of pNTP to para-aminothiophenol (pATP) was observed on Au/TiO2/Pt. As compared with Pt/TiO2, Au/TiO2/Pt is more active. The authors also prepared Au/SiO2/Pt by replacing TiO2 by SiO2. But the pNTP cannot be hydrogenated on Au/SiO2/Pt. These results suggested that the hydrogen was activated on the Pt surface and the dissociated hydrogen spills over from Pt to TiO2 and finally reaches the surface of Au for the hydrogenation of pNTP adsorbed on Au to pATP. The high activity of Au/TiO2/Pt is attributed to the sandwich nanostructure with spatially separated Pt and Au as the active sites for hydrogen dissociation and pATP activation, respectively. Qin et al. [ 54 ] designed closely contacted CoOxPt/TiO2 and spatially separated CoOx/TiO2/Pt by ALD (Fig. 2(a) ). In the selective hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes to unsaturated alcohols, the monometallic TiO2/Pt catalyst exhibited 16.2% selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol (CALC) at 93.1% conversion. In contrast to TiO2/Pt, both closely contacted CoOxPt/TiO2 and spatially separated CoOx/TiO2/Pt catalysts demonstrated significantly enhanced selectivity (82.1% and 81.5%) to CALC at high conversions (92.4% and 91.3%). In situ XAFS results revealed that CoOx was reduced to a lower valence state, which facilitated hydrogen spillover under reaction conditions. The consumption of active hydrogen species by CoOx promotes the generation and transfer of hydrogen species. The accelerated hydrogen spillover leads to an increase in the concentration of Ov through the reduction of TiO2 support proved by in situ Ti K-edge XANES spectra. Theoretical computational results showed that CALD molecule is more stably adsorbed on Ov through C=O bond. Therefore, the high selectivity of CoOxPt/TiO2 and CoOx/TiO2/Pt is related with the increased amounts of Ov (Fig. 2(b)). The completion of the reaction necessitates the collaboration of multiple sites. Specifically, Pt is responsible for adsorbing and dissociating hydrogen, while CoOx enhances hydrogen overflow efficiency to promote the generation of Ov. Finally, carbonyl groups are activated on these Ov to be hydrogenated. Yang and co-workers [ 55 ] developed a spatially separated dual metal catalyst Ru/Pd/MCMOS with Ru NPs and Pd NPs respectively on the groove surface and within the interior nanocavities using multi-compartmentalized mesoporous organosilica (MCMOS) as support for the cascade hydrogenation of nitrobenzene (NB) to cyclohexylamine (CA) (Figs. 3(a)–(c) ). This transformation involves two sequential steps: nitro hydrogenation and aromatic ring hydrogenation. The Ru/Pd/MCMOS cascade catalyst gives the final product CA in 99.2% yield within 2.5 h under mild reaction conditions (80 °C, 2.0 MPa). In contrast, no CA could be detected over the monometallic Pd/MCMOS and Ru/MCMOS under the same reaction conditions. This difference is attributed to the fact that Pd/MCMOS is active only in the conversion of NB to AN (the first step), while Ru/MCMOS is active only in the hydrogenation of AN to CA. Moreover, the CA production rate of Ru/Pd/MCMOS was calculated to be as high as 27.4 h−1, which is 7.72-fold higher than that of physically mixed catalyst and 3.4-fold higher than that of Pd-Ru/DSNs without spatial isolation, indicating the important role of nanochannels of MCMOS and isolation of dual metal. In summary, the synergy of Pd NPs, Ru NPs and nanochannels of MCMOS promotes the efficient conversion of NB to AC over Ru/Pd/MCMOS, Pd NPs is responsible for the hydrogenation of NB to AN, Ru is in charge of the hydrogenation of AN to CA, and the nanochannels facilitate molecular transfer. The above examples successfully prepared spatial isolated bi-metallic catalysts. Because the two metals are separated in different space of the catalysts, the electronic and geometric structures of the two metal nanoparticles are identical to the corresponding monometallic ones. Thus, the promotion effect of the bi-metallic catalysts and the role of different active sites in the catalytic reactions have been clearly verified. In addition to spatial separation of the two metals, Lu et al. [ 56 ] constructed Au@Pt core-shell bimetallic NPs catalyst with precisely controlled shell thickness of Pt on gold NPs (~5.3 nm) by ALD technology. In the chemoselective hydrogenation of p-CNB, the 5.3 nm-Au catalyst showed almost no activity, due to its limited ability for H2 dissociation. However, Au@1ML-Pt (1ML refers to 0.21 nm of platinum shell in Fig. 3(a)) exhibited a remarkable activity along with a 99% p-CAN selectivity. The specific activity of Au@1ML-Pt is 3.44×104 molp-CNB molPt h−1, much higher than that of Au x Pt y alloy catalysts and 2.7nm-Pt catalyst. Moreover, Au@1ML-Pt also exhibited excellent stability throughout the catalytic cycles (Figs. 4(b), 4(d), 4(e) ). The significant impact of ligands and the stretching of the platinum lattice shell induced by the gold core lead to a substantial shift in the d-band center of platinum towards Fermi level as shown in Fig. 4(c). Therefore, the high exposure of Pt and optimized d-band center of Pt induced by the strong electronic interactions between platinum and gold result in the excellent catalytic performance of Au@1ML-Pt. 3 Combination of metal NPs and single atom Single atom catalysts (SAs) were first reported by Zhang and co-authors in 2011 [ 57 ]. SACs with uniform dispersion of single atoms exhibit 100% atom usage efficiency. Besides, the well-defined single active centers possess highly active valence electrons, experience quantum confinement effects, and showcase a sparse quantum level of metal atoms [ 58–62 ]. It is widely acknowledged that the interplay between catalysts and reactants is heavily influenced by the configurations of d orbitals. Norskov and co-workers have proposed the d-band theory, which has proven remarkably effective in predicting the adsorption strength of pivotal intermediates, consequently elucidating the catalytic performances of transition metals [ 63 ]. As the size decrease from nanoparticles (NPs) to single atoms (SAs), the electronic energy levels transfer from a quasi-continuous state to a discrete state. This transformation reduces the atomic coordination number of the metal and upshifts the d band center position. Compared with NPs, the upward shift of the d-band center position of SAs results in an increase in the anti-bonding energy bands generated by coupling. Consequently, more anti-bonding energy bands are positioned above the Fermi level, thereby enhancing the stability of bonding by increasing electron filling and strengthening adsorption [ 64 ]. Consequently, the polar unsaturated bond will preferentially adsorb and activate on SAs rather than NPs in the selective hydrogenations [ 65,66 ]. However, metal single-atom catalysts often require higher temperatures for catalytic hydrogenation reactions due to the higher activation energy of hydrogen dissociation [ 67 ]. There is a distinct volcano-shaped pattern in the relationship between hydrogen dissociation ability and metal size. As the metal size increases, the hydrogen dissociation ability initially rises and then decreases, reaching optimal performance around 2 nm [ 7,68,69 ]. Therefore, coupling single atoms and nanoparticles can simultaneously improve the activity and selectivity of selective hydrogenation. The synergy of metal NPs and single atoms harnesses the distinct advantages of both components, such as the highly exposed active sites and relatively uniform coordination microenvironment of single atoms, and the high H2 dissociation ability of metal nanoparticles [ 70–72 ]. Critically, the coexistence of metal NPs and SAs provides a higher degree of freedom in electronic modulations for both, resulting in multifunctional active sites with divergent electronic properties. This innovative approach not only addresses the challenge of competitive adsorption but also presents an avenue for enhancing the overall catalytic efficiency and versatility of supported metal catalysts in hydrogenation reactions. The hydrogenation of ketones and aldehydes stands as a crucial industrial method for alcohol production, yet the presence of competitive side reactions, such as deep hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation, often diminishes selectivity to alcohols especially at high conversion. Baoyou Geng et al. [ 70 ] reported a Pd1+NPs/TiO2 catalyst with both Pd NPs and SAs (Pd1) supported on TiO2. In the hydrogenation of 4-methylacetophenone (MAP), the substrate undergoes complete conversion within 1.0 h with a remarkable alcohol selectivity of 99% over Pd1+NPs/TiO2. The activity of Pd1+NPs/TiO2 is 3.2 times superior to Pd/C with 84% selectivity under complete conversion conditions. This breakthrough eliminates the typical trade-off between activity and selectivity. In comparison, Pd1/TiO2 and PdNPs/TiO2 achieve 50% and 73.6% conversion of MAP, respectively (Figs. 5(a) and 5(b) ), both with a 99% selectivity for alcohol under identical reaction conditions. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation suggests that Pd1 with lower C=O adsorption energy played a crucial role in activating C=O group, and Pd NPs acting as H2 dissociation sites facilitated the homolytic dissociation of H2. Therefore, the outstanding catalytic performance of Pd1+NPs/TiO2 is attributed to the synergistic interaction between Pd1 and PdNPs (Fig. 5(c)). This combination effectively leverages the hydrogen dissociation capability of nanoparticles and the carbonyl activation ability of single atoms, thereby enhancing overall performance. Similarly, the synergy of SA and metal NPs also shows the unique properties in the hydrogenation of quinoline. The strong adsorption of quinoline on metal surface usually causes the low activity of supported metal NPs. Zhao et al. [ 71 ] reported that the Ir1+NPs/CMK catalyst containing both Ir SA (Ir1) and Ir NPs with a turnover frequency of 7800 h−1 is more active than Ir1/CMK and IrNPs/CMK (Fig. 6(a) ) [ 71 ]. It should be noted that Ir1+NPs/CMK is 20000 times more active than commercial Ir/C, a benchmark catalyst for quinoline hydrogenation. Hydrogen-deuterium exchange kinetics experiment gives a K H/K D value of 1.7, 1.8 and 2.5 respectively for Ir1+NP, IrNP and Ir1 (Fig. 6(b)), which proved that the dissociation of H2 takes place mainly on the Ir NPs for Ir1+NP/CMK. This conclusion was further confirmed by DFT calculations. The Ir1 with slightly positive charge may be the anchoring site for quinoline, which can decrease the competitive quinoline adsorption with H2 on Ir NPs, resulting in the high activity of Ir1+NP/CMK (Fig. 6(c)). In addition to single catalytic reactions, the synergy of SA and metal NPs is also beneficial for improving the activity and selectivity of tandem/cascade reactions, which generally involve different types of reactions, thus, improving the activity and selectivity of each step is vital for obtaining both the high activity and high selectivity. Taking the reductive amination of cyclohexanone to cyclohexylamine as an example, there are two parallel paths to produce cyclohexylamine. The first one is the condensation of cyclohexanone and ammonia to form imine intermediate followed by the reduction of imine to cyclohexylamine. The second reaction pathway is the condensation of cyclohexanone and cyclohexylamine to form Schiff base intermediate, and then the Schiff base is reductively aminated at acid site to form cyclohexylamine (Fig. 7(a) ). Han et al. [ 73 ] found that Co@C-N(800) possessing both Co SA and Co NPs gave > 99% conversion together with > 99% selectivity in the reductive amination of cyclohexanone to cyclohexylamine (Fig. 7(b)). However, only 9.5% cyclohexanamine was obtained with only Co NPs and the main product (91%) was the Schiff base intermediate, indicating that Co NPs catalyzes the reaction through the second reaction pathway and Co NPs cannot convert the Schiff base intermediate into the desired product. In addition, no cyclohexanol was generated over Co SAs due to the weak hydrogenation activity of Co SAs. Therefore, Co NPs promoted the hydrogenation step, while the Co-Nx sites acted as acidic sites to activate the Schiff base intermediate. The cooperation of SA and metal NPs was also demonstrated in the cascade dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to phenol with cyclohexanone as intermediate (Fig. 8 ). This cascade dehydrogenation includes several C−H and O−H bonds activation. Ma and co-authors found that the isolated Rh SA (Rh1) gave the turnover frequency as high as ∼3600 h−1 for the partial dehydrogenation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexanone, but is almost inactive for the subsequent dehydrogenation of cyclohexanone to phenol. In contrast, Rh NPs (RhNP) are highly active for the dehydrogenation of cyclohexanone to phenol. Therefore, Rh1+NP/ND@G catalyst with the coexistence of Rh1 and RhNP was prepared and the yield of phenol was significantly promoted, showing the advantages of the synergy of Rh1 and RhNP [ 72 ]. Due to their different d-band structures, single atoms and metal nanoparticles can specifically catalyze a certain step to accelerate the entire reaction process. Recently, synergistic catalysis between Pd single atoms (SAs) and Pd clusters in the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde (CAL) has been reported [ 74 ]. CAL molecules contain both C=C and C=O unsaturated groups, both of which can be hydrogenated (Fig. 9(a) ). Therefore, the corresponding selective hydrogenation products include hydrogenated cinnamaldehyde (HCAL), cinnamyl alcohol (COL), and hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCOL). A Pd-based catalyst with high selectivity for the hydrogenation of C=C is essential for the preparation of HCAL. Cheng et al. [ 74 ] prepared a PdSA+C/g-C3N4 catalyst comprising Pd-N3 single atoms and Pd subnanoclusters. In the CAL hydrogenation reaction, the PdSA+C/g-C3N4 catalyst exhibits 97.3% HCAL selectivity at 100% CAL conversion and can be recycled for 16 times (Fig. 9(c)), with a turnover frequency (TOF) value of 9.19 s–1, which is 12 times higher than that of PdSA/g-C3N4 (0.76 s–1) and 3 times higher than that of PdNPs/g-C3N4 (2.84 s–1) (Fig. 9(b)). DFT calculations revealed that the adsorption energy of CAL on the single-atom site is lower in the presence of both Pd single atoms and clusters, indicating a strong interaction between CAL and Pd single atoms. Additionally, H2 exhibits a lower adsorption energy at the Pd cluster site compared to the Pd single-atom site in the coexistence model, suggesting that H2 will preferentially adsorb on Pd clusters. Therefore, the excellent activity of PdSA+C for the selective hydrogenation of CAL is mainly due to the cooperation of PdSA site to activate the C=C bond of CAL, the Pd cluster site to dissociate H2, and hydrogen spillover from the Pd cluster to the Pd single atom to complete the hydrogenation reaction as shown in Fig. 9(d). In addition to the synergistic effects between single atoms and nanoparticles or nanoclusters, synergistic effects between dual single atoms also play a significant role in hydrogenation reactions. Huang et al. [ 75 ] presented a dual single-atom catalyst Ir1Mo1/TiO2, synthesized through the pyrolysis of a bimetallic carbonyl cluster. In the hydrogenation of 4-nitrostyrene (4-NS), Ir1Mo1/TiO2 exhibited > 96% chemoselectivity for 4-vinylaniline (4-VA) at 100% conversion. In contrast, Mo1/TiO2 displayed no activity, and Ir1/TiO2 showed 87% conversion with 38% selectivity for 4-VA under the same reaction condition. DFT calculation results show that the 4-NS preferentially adopted on Mo atoms through nitro groups. The dissociation barrier between H2 on Ir is much lower than that on Mo or Ti, indicating that Ir atoms will activate H2 instead of Mo or Ti atoms (Fig. 10(a) ). Therefore, during the hydrogenation of 4-NS on Ir1Mo1/TiO2, Mo1 adsorbs 4-NS through nitro, and Ir1 activates H2, and the cooperation of the two sites leads to enhanced activity and selectivity for the production of aniline. Ren et al. [ 76 ] designed a Pt1-Fe1/ND catalyst by anchoring Pt single atoms on Fe1-N4 sites for the hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes (CNB). Under the reaction conditions of T = 80 °C and P H2 = 1 MPa, neither Pt1/ND nor Fe1/ND showed activity within 20 min. In contrast, Pt1Fe1/ND achieved 100% conversion and 100% selectivity to p-chloroaniline (Fig. 10(b)). Attenuated total reflectance infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy of p-NB adsorbed on Pt1Fe1/ND suggests that the nitro group is preferentially adsorbed on Fe1 site rather than Pt1 site. DFT calculation studies clearly illustrate that hydrogen is activated on Pt1-Fe1 dual site. Therefore, the exceptional catalytic performance of Pt1Fe1/ND is attributed to the division of labor, with Fe1 activating the nitro group and Pt1Fe1 activating the hydrogen. 4 Combination of metal NPs with organometallic complexes Besides supported metal NPs, organometallic complexes are the most often used catalysts in homogeneous hydrogenation [ 77–79 ]. The well-developed supported metal NPs and organometallic complexes both have unique properties, for example, organometallic complexes have uniform active sites which are beneficial for regio/stereo-selectivity control and supported metal NPs have strong H2 dissociation ability. The combination of organometallic complexes with supported metal catalysts can improve the activity and selectivity of hydrogenation reaction, but it has rarely been reported. Yang and co-authors [ 80 ] reported the synergy of organometallic complexes and supported metal NPs for H2 driven NAD(P)H regeneration (cofactor nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (phosphate)). They found that the coupling of [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ (abbreviated as M1, bpy = 2,2’-bipyridine) and supported Ru NPs gave > 99% selectivity at full conversion in the hydrogenation of NAD+ (oxidized form of NADH), but only 83.0% and 38.4% selectivity at full conversion were observed for M1 and supported Ru NPs, respectively. The reaction rate of the coupling system was about 15-folds to the sum total of M1 and supported Ru NPs separately (Figs. 11(a) and (b) ). The reaction mechanism suggests a novel hydrogenation mode through H species relay from supported Ru NPs to M1, where the Ru NPs and M1 are responsible for H2 dissociation and hydride transferring to NAD+ (Fig. 11(c)). Furthermore, the metal NPs in the coupling system can also be replaced by Pt, Rh, Pd and Ni, and Ru, Rh, and Ir complexes can be used instead of M1. Later, the same group reported the preparation of a core-shell nanoreactor for H2-driven NAD(P)H regeneration by the encapsulation of Ni/TiO2 with a Rh complex coordinated 3D porous organic polymer (POP) (Fig. 11(d)) [ 81 ]. In comparison with single Ni NPs or immobilized Rh complex, the integrated catalyst simultaneously exhibited enhanced activity and selectivity in NAD(P)H regeneration due to the cooperation of H2 dissociation, hydride transferring and the rapid hydrogen spillover. Additionally, by coupling the H2-driven NADPH regeneration core-shell nanoreactor with aldehyde ketone reductase (AKR) catalyzed asymmetric reduction of acetophenone, they found that the relative activity of AKR in the presence of Ni/TiO2@POP-BPY-Rh0.71 was always much higher than that in the presence of [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ (Fig. 11(e)) and up to 96% ee was obtained and NADPH could be regenerated at least 17 cycles. 5 Combination of metal NPs with immobilized ligands With the deep research of the heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation, researchers have discovered that the activation of unsaturated bonds can be accomplished not only by supported metal NPs but also by the specific immobilized organic ligands on porous materials, such as MOFs [ 82–84 ], polymers [ 85,86 ] and organo-functionalized mesoporous silicas (OFSMs) [ 87 ]. Compared with free organic ligands, immobilized organic ligands offer significant advantages for the modification of metal catalysts. Firstly, they prevent the blocking of active sites to a large extent, ensuring the high exposure degree of active sites while modifying the geometry and electronic structure of metal NPs. Secondly, the immobilization of organic ligands prevents the leaching of organic ligand during the catalytic process, allowing it to be recycled and reducing the steps of product purification [ 88 ]. The recent progresses in the combination of metal NPs and MOFs can refer to the previous reports and reviews. We will mainly introduce the works related with the combination of metal NPs and polymers/OFSMs. As compared with the surface modification of metal NPs with organic ligands, the combination of metal NPs and organic ligands integrated in porous materials can avoid organic ligand leaching and effectively manipulate the electronic and local coordination structure of metal NPs. Yang and co-authors [ 87 ] used a series of organo-functionalized mesoporous silicas (FDU) to load Ru nanoparticles for the hydrogenation of benzoic acid. In the hydrogenation of benzoic acid using n-hexane as solvent, Ru loaded on FDU, NH2-FDU (amine modified FDU using aminopropyltriethoxysilane) and Ph@FDU (with polystyrene in the nanopore of FDU) showed no activity, while Ru loaded on PPh2-FDU (PPh2 modified FDU using 2-(diphenylphosphino)ethyltriethoxysilane) and PPh3@FDU (with polytriphenylphosphine in the nanopore of FDU) exhibited catalytic activity. Therefore, the presence of phosphine ligands near Ru nanoparticles triggers a transition from inactive Ru to active one in the hydrogenation of benzoic acid in n-hexane (Fig. 12(b) ). DFT calculations showed that the phosphine ligands surrounding the Ru nanoparticles could interact with the –COOH group of benzoic acid with a suitable adsorption strength, which leads to the oriented adsorption of benzoic acid on the Ru surface and promotes the catalytic activity. The lower activity observed in Ru/NH2-FDU is attributed to the sluggish desorption of products due to the strong interaction between –NH2 and benzoic acid (Fig. 12(c)). Conversely, the weak interaction of Ru/FDU with benzoic acid failed to induce the oriented adsorption of benzoic acid on the Ru surface. The covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are rich in organic moiety and can provide versatile interactions near metal NPs. Yang and co-authors [ 89 ] reported the loading of Pd NPs on COFs with different conjugated skeletons (Fig. 13(a) ). The Pd NPs on different COFs have similar particle size and surface electronic/geometric structures but different chemical environments. In the hydrogenation of acetophenone (AP), the TOF of Pd/pyrene-COF (with pyrene in the framework of COFs) was approximately 5.5 and 6.5-folds that of Pd/Be-COF and Pd/TB-COF without pyrene ligands. The selectivity of alcohol approached >99% over both Pd/COFs, much higher than that of Pd/C (Figs. 13(b) and (c)). This indicates a significant change in the activity and selectivity of AP hydrogenation via the modulation of the microenvironment surrounding the Pd nanoparticles. The high activity of Pd/pyrene-COF is primarily attributed to π–π interactions between pyrene rings and AP, which can stabilize the transition state during the catalytic process (Fig. 13(d)). Additionally, Pd/pyrene-COF is more active than Pd/ Be-COFs in the hydrogenation of polar functional groups of aromatic compounds, such as 2-acetonaphthone, 2-naphthaldehyde furfural and benzofuran, which further highlights the crucial role of weak interactions in enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity. The same group found that COF can activate the carbonyl group and the presence of COFs significantly promotes both the activity and selectivity of Pt/SiO2 in the hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds [ 90 ]. Specifically, the addition of K-N-COF (structure in Fig. 14(c) ) resulted in an increased selectivity to phenyl ethanol from 27.1% to 69.0% over Pt/SiO2 (Pt, 1.2 nm) in the hydrogenation of acetophenone (AP) in ethanol (Figs. 14(a) and 14(b)). Notably, this selectivity improvement was not observed when the reaction was carried out in hexane. It was proposed that this promotional effect stems from the carbonyl activation by K-N-COF, H2 dissociation by Pt and the H spillover. Building on these findings, a multisite catalyst, Pt/K-N-COF/SiO2, was prepared by integrating Pt/SiO2 with K-N-COF. Pt/K-N-COF/SiO2 exhibited higher activity and selectivity (94.7%) than Pt/SiO2, and the turnover frequency (TOF) is 16 times that of Pt/SiO2. A series of experimental verifications demonstrated that the close contact between Pt/SiO2 and the thin layer of K-N-COF significantly improves the activity and selectivity of Pt in the hydrogenation of aromatic ketones and aliphatic ketones to the corresponding alcohols (Fig. 14(c)). This approach leverages the synergistic catalysis of carbonyl hydrogenation on COF sites, H2 dissociation on Pt, and hydrogen transfer through SiO2. 6 Conclusions and perspectives The multi-site catalysts with distinct functions have successfully addressed the trade-off between activity and selectivity observed in single-site catalysts for heterogeneous hydrogenations, highlighting the collaborative synergy between isolated sites. In this review, we have summarized a series of representative multi-site heterogeneous catalysts with spatially separated active sites, including the combination of two different metal NPs, metal NPs with single atom, metal NPs with immobilized ligands, and metal NPs with metal complex, and elucidated the crucial functions of these isolated sites in the hydrogenation process. The high performance of multi-site catalysts is mainly attributed to the followings: (1) avoiding the competitive adsorption of different reactants, (2) activating different reactants on different sites, (4) retaining the intrinsic properties of the active sites when dual/multi-sites are formed, (5) optimizing the rate control step to accelerate the overall reaction. Nevertheless, the development of rational, efficient, and robust dual-site catalyst remains a challenge and an important task at present, wherein some foreseeable challenges require serious attention before their success. Apart from the selective hydrogenation mentioned above, the catalyst with isolated dual/multi- site has also demonstrated unique properties in other thermal catalysis [ 91–97 ], photocatalysis [ 99,100 ] and electrocatalysis [ 101,102 ]. In the “relay type” catalytic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), Zhang et al. [ 103 ] discovered that (Co1→Cop)/N-CNT with two cobalt active sites (single atoms Co1 and nanoparticles CoNPs) can achieve efficient production of FDCA. The Co1 site facilitates the oxidation of hydroxymethyl groups to aldehyde groups, while the CoNPs site exhibits higher activity for the conversion of aldehyde groups to carboxyl groups. In CO2 photoreduction, Xiang et al. [ 104 ] developed dual-single-atom Co and Ru supported on conjugated porous carbon nitride polymer (HCNp). The average photocatalytic rate for CO evolution over CoRu-HCNp is nearly 2-, 5-, and 3-folds higher than that of Ru-HCNp, Co-HCNp and HCNp under similar conditions. The combination of Co and Ru SAs effectively promotes the activity and CO-selectivity. In detail, the active Co sites facilitate dynamic charge transfer, while the Ru sites promote selective CO2 surface-bound interaction during CO2 photoreduction. Similarly, Li et al. [ 102 ] reported a cobalt carbon catalyst Co/CoNx-C with a dual structure of cobalt single atom/cobalt nanoparticle, which has both cobalt nanoparticles to enhance oxygen adsorption and cobalt single atom to maximize atomic utilization and enhance oxygen reduction ability, the dual sites can synergistically promote electrocatalytic oxygen reduction, showing excellent electrocatalytic performance. The challenges for the robust dual/multi-site catalyst remain in the following aspects: (1) Currently, the preparation of spatially isolated dual/multi-site catalysts with precisely controlled location, for example the distance between different active sites is still challenging. Recently, Aizenberg and co-workers [ 105 ] employed a raspberry colloidal template method to adjust the average particle distance of PdAu alloy nanoparticles while preserving all other physicochemical properties, including nanoparticle size. However, the efficient modulation of the distance of different nanoparticles on the solid support has been barely reported. Hence, the development of new technique that can precisely control the location of different active site under mild preparation conditions and has the possibility for the preparation in large scale is highly desirable for practical application of the dual/multi-site catalyst in industry. (2) The existing collaborations between single atoms and nanoparticles typically include the arrangement of heterogeneity single atoms around the nanoparticles. There is currently no literature addressing the influence of single atom density on synergistic performance. Therefore, additional research should focus on achieving adjustable distances, densities, and ratios of single atoms to nanoparticles to investigate the origin of their synergistic effect. Moreover, achieving precise control over the exact number of single atoms and nanoparticles on the catalyst surface remains a challenge. There are currently two main methods for the preparation of catalysts with the coexistence of single atoms and nanoparticles of homonuclear metals, namely the post-loading and in-situ synthesis method [ 106 ]. The post-loading method refers to the loading of metal sites onto the as-prepared supports and activation treating of loaded metal species to metal SAs and NPs. The metal species are generally captured and anchored by the defect or anion sites of the supports, the activation treatment includes washing, drying, and reduction. However, the reduction of metal precursor to metal SAs and NPs is hard to be controlled. The in-situ generation method refers to the one-pot formation of metal NPs and single atoms on the support by carbonization, which has been widely used for the preparation of M-N-C materials. Owing to the high temperature carbonization, it is difficult to control the particle size of metal NPs and the relative density of single atoms and metal NPs. Consequently, the unclear correlation between the synergistic effects and the relative content of these two metal species restricts the further optimization of the metal dosages. (3) The catalytic systems composed of specific immobilized functional groups and reactants still lack enzyme-like specificity and selectivity. Additionally, the inevitable adsorption of functional groups on metal surface can lead to the loss of some active sites. Furthermore, the interaction between the functional group and reactant molecule requires more experimental verification before universal matching patterns can be systematically summarized. Catalysis stands as the cornerstone of chemistry, driving the engines of the chemical industry forward. Categorically, catalysts encompass enzymes, homogeneous catalysts, and heterogeneous catalysts, each with distinct application scopes, merits, and limitations. Enzymes, derived from nature and integral to biological processes, exhibit remarkable high activity and high chemo/stereo/chiral selectivity under environmentally friendly and mild conditions. Typically, the exceptional efficiency of natural enzymes stems from the synergistic interactions among multiple active sites. Moreover, enzymes demonstrate high selectivity, often recognizing only specific substrates, thereby limiting the range of applicable reaction substrates. Conversely, broad-spectrum and efficient metal catalysts find extensive use in industrial chemistry, albeit under harsh reaction conditions, posing challenges in achieving high selectivity. Therefore, combining enzymes with homogeneous or heterogeneous catalytic processes is an effective strategy with the potential to achieve both high selectivity and substrate versatility [ 107,108 ]. Collaborative catalysis between enzymes and homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts relies on the distinct sites offered by enzymes and homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts, or when enzymes combined with metal catalysis, engender novel artificial active sites [ 107,109,110 ]. For example, Ge et al. [ 105 ] anchored single metal atoms on enzymes and constructed a stable single-atom enzyme-metal complex. The cooperative catalysis between lipase-active site and single Pd atom accelerates alkyl-alkyl cross-coupling reaction which is 300 times higher than the traditional catalyst Pd(OAc)2 under ambient conditions. Similarly, Yang et al. [ 111 ] achieved the integration of homogeneous or biological catalysts with heterogeneous ones by filling Pickering micron emulsion droplets with encapsulated biocatalyst enzymes and solid particle catalysts in column reactors to construct a continuous flow reaction system. Surprisingly, the spatially isolated biocatalysts and heterogeneous catalysts have their own liquid microenvironments, and the directional transfer of intermediates enables efficient collaboration of different catalysts in a continuous flow system. In the chemical enzyme coupling reaction to synthesize chiral cyanohydrins and chiral esters, the catalytic efficiency of the system in which the enzyme and solid catalyst cooperated was 7 to 77 times higher than that of the batch reaction, and the enantioselectivity reached 99%, and the long-term Stable operation (240 h). Currently, there is a lack of research results on synergistic catalyst systems for hydrogenation involving enzymes and homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. Complex multi-step catalytic reactions entail substantial energy and material consumption, often yielding low product yields. However, consolidating these reactions within a single reactor and under unified conditions holds promise for significantly reducing energy and material consumption while alleviating separation and purification pressures. Considering the distinct characteristics and advantages of the three types of catalysts, interdisciplinary collaboration is anticipated to be a novel approach for designing hydrogenation catalysts, particularly for reactions involving stereoselectivity. Integrating muti-sites together is an effective strategy to achieve both high selectivity and substrate versatility in selective hydrogenation. References 1 F.F.D. Formenti F.K. Scharnagl M. Qihua Yang (Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University) received her Ph.D. degree in Inorganic Chemistry from Northeast Normal University in 1997. She did postdoctoral research in State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (China), LCOMS-CNRS/CPE (France), and Toyota Central R&D Labs. Inc. (Japan). She was promoted to full professor in 2003. Her research interests are mainly focused on the synthesis of hybrid porous materials for heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis and nano-catalysis. She is the author or co-author of more than 200 peer-reviewed scientific publications.

coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous hydrogenation with supported metal catalyst is one of the efficient methods for producing fine chemicals. Hydrogenation reactions for fine chemical production often use reactants with more than one unsaturated bond or involve cascade multiple-step reactions, facing the dilemma of activity and selectivity. The dual-site or multi-site catalysts have been employed to solve this dilemma, but the entanglement at different sites generally cannot improve selectivity without reducing activity. In this review, we will introduce recent progresses in the construction of dual-site supported metal catalysts with division of active site, which may break the tradeoff between activity and selectivity in selective hydrogenation considering that each active sites can be modulated separately without causing the property variation of other sites. In addition, such catalysts contribute to the basic understanding of their structure-activity relationship and provide a theoretical basis for the development of efficient hydrogenation catalysts for fine chemical production.
